Ivan Sutherland

Biography and contributions

Ivan Edward Sutherland, age 83, was born in Hasting, Nebraska (US), on the 16th May 1938. In 1959 he received his Bachelor of Science Degree from the Carnegie Institute of Technology in electrical engineering. In 1960 he obtained his Master of Science Degree at the Caltech and in 1963 he was awarded his Ph.D. in EECS from MIT. In 1966, he also received an honorary Master Degree of Arts from Harvard University in 1966.
After his Ph.D. Sutherland served as military officer in the U.S Army commission, where he was assigned as an electrical engineer. In 1964 he became head of the U.S. Department of Defense Advanced Research Project Agency's (DARPA) Information Processing Techniques Office (IPTO). Here he managed a yearly budget of 15 million USD for computer research in time-sharing and artificial intelligence.
From 1965 to 1978 Sutherland was an academic at various universities. From 1965 to 1968, he was an Associate Professor of Electrical Engineering at Harvard University, where he developed the Cohen–Sutherland computer graphics line clipping algorithm. In 1968 he created the first virtual reality and augmented reality in collaboration with his student Sproull. From 1968 to 1974 Sutherland was a Professor of Computer Science at the University of Utah.
In 1968 Sutherland and David C. Evans founded Evans & Sutherland where they were the leading experts in the field of real-time hardware 3D computer graphics, and printer languages.
From 1974 to 1978 Sutherland was the founding head of the Computer Science department at California Institute of Technology, and then, in 1980, he started a consulting firm under the name “Sutherland, Sproull and Associates”.
His other important findings are the characterization and categorization of hidden surface algorithms (1974), the Trojan Cockroach, a machine with 6 legs that could walk around (1983), and most importantly the Sketchpad, the first interactive computer-graphics program, for which he won the Turing Award. For more information about his Turing award follow the link below.

Awards and Honors
1955-1959 George Westinghouse Scholar
1958-1959 American Institute of Electrical Engineers Student Prize Paper Contest (District 2 Winner)
1959-1962 National Science Foundation Fellowship
1972 National Academy of Engineering First Zworykin Award
1973 Member, National Academy of Engineering
1978 Member, National Academy of Sciences
1986 IIEEE Emanuel R. Piore Award
1987 Computerworld Honors Program, Leadership Award
1988 ACM Turing Award
1993 ACM Software System Award
1994 Electronic Frontier Foundation EFF Pioneer Award
1994 Association for Computing Machinery Fellow
1996 Price Waterhouse Information Technology Leadership Award for Lifetime Achievement
1996 Computerworld Smithsonian Award
1996 the Franklin Institute's Certificate of Merit
1998 IEEE John von Neumann Medal
2004 R&D 100 Award (team)
2005 Computer History Museum Fellow
1998 Kyoto Prize
Turing Award 1988

In memory of A.M. Turing
